Packaging Automation

Greedy, recursive

Given a list of items in groups, perform certain operations in order to satisfy the constaints required by packaging automation.The conditions are as follows:

  1. The first group must contain 1 item only.
  2. For all the other groups, the difference between the number of items in adjacent groups must be greater than 1. In other words, for 1 <= i <= n, arr[i] - arr[i - 1] <= 1. To accomplish this, the following operations are available:

Write an algorithm to find the maximum items that can be packaged for the final group of the list given the conditions above.

Example - 1 – arr = [3, 1, 3, 4]. Output: 4. Explanation: Subtract 1 from the first group making the list [2, 1, 3, 4]. Rearrange the list into [1, 2, 3, 4]. The final maximum of items that can be packaged in the last group is 4.

Example 2 - arr = [1, 1, 1, 1]. Output is 1.

根据我的理解上面这个答案应该是很有问题的，题目中说明可以将>1的降到1，上面解法在不断地加数字而不是减

这个没有仔细看，不确定对不对，似乎题目不允许上调

Min Cost to Connect All Nodes || Min Cost to Connect All Servers || Minimum Spanning Tree

Min Cost to Repair Edges (Minimum Spanning Tree II)

Data Center Critical Connection

https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/356981

Min Distance Between Robots || Minimum Squared Distance || Squared Shortest Distance

https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/closest-pair-of-points-using-divide-and-conquer-algorithm/

Divide and conquer, cut it in half and calculate the minDist in two parts, and then calculate the middle part, pick points that has xDist and yDist shorter than current minDist

题目在OA2 materials part里

2019 Treasure Island II // dfs

Min Cost to Repair Edges (Minimum Spanning Tree II)

Movies on Flight

You are on a flight and wanna watch two movies during this flight.
You are given int[] movie_duration which includes all the movie durations.
You are also given the duration of the flight which is d in minutes.
Now, you need to pick two movies and the total duration of the two movies is less than or equal to (d - 30min).
Find the pair of movies with the longest total duration. If multiple found, return the pair with the longest movie.

e.g.
Input
movie_duration: [90, 85, 75, 60, 120, 150, 125]
d: 250

Output from aonecode.com
[90, 125]
90min + 125min = 215 is the maximum number within 220 (250min - 30min)

⭐7. Critical Routers

You are given an undirected connected graph.

An articulation point (or cut vertex) is defined as a vertex which, when removed along with associated edges, makes the graph disconnected (or more precisely, increases the number of connected components in the graph).

The task is to find all articulation points in the given graph.

articulation points && bridge

Input:
The input to the function/method consists of three arguments:

  • numNodes, an integer representing the number of nodes in the graph.
  • numEdges, an integer representing the number of edges in the graph.
  • edges, the list of pair of integers - A, B representing an edge between the nodes A and B.

Output:
Return a list of integers representing the critical nodes.

Example:

explanation video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZXi1unBdJA

Maximal Square

Python

OA1

发表于 2021-02-21 分类于 Amazon

OA1

新题

  1. 没做过的题，是一个二分法的题——答案是把mid+1变成mid

OA1图片

https://www.evernote.com/shard/s683/client/snv?noteGuid=d0047552-4cff-4c29-b305-b8aa2d33f364&noteKey=636f07d57c2eb3ea&sn=https://www.evernote.com/shard/s683/sh/d0047552-4cff-4c29-b305-b8aa2d33f364/636f07d57c2eb3ea&title=Amazon+OA1+Debugging

旧题目17道：

evenodd

reversearray

sortarray

replacevalues

countocc

countdigit

printpattern

  1. replace Values: 把for循环条件里i<= len 和 j<=len 改成 i< len 和 j<len

  2. check Grade: || 改 &&, 根据分数return ABCD，其中两个判断条件有||，比如x>=60|| x < 75都改成&&

  3. print Pattern : for循环少了大括号, for-loop里一共两句话但是没有用大括号，所以第二句没有被包含进去

  4. count occurrence: while loop里加i++

  5. sortArray: line 13 if (max > arr[j]) 改成 max < arr[j] ，compile一下就能看出来排完的顺序反了

  6. manchester: 这个有两处错误，是要判断array里每位数字和前面一位是不是相等，index0的数字单独和0判断一下，所以0那句不能直接res[0]= 0要res[0] = (arr[0] != 0) ? 1:0，后面for循环里判断是要把arr == arr[i-1]改成arr != arr[i-1]。曼切斯特如果arr[i-1],arr相等为0，否则为1，要注意不但==要改成!=，ret[0]也要加一下，不然有一个case过不了。

  7. print Character Pattern : print的时候题目里是ch++要改成print++，不然ch一直变就没法从a开始print了

  8. odd Even Number: for循环少了大括号{}

  9. reverse Array: len += 1改成len -=1, arr[len-1]改成arr[len-i-1], 循环结束前去掉len+=1;

  10. remove Element: arr =arr[i++]改成arr =arr[i+1]

  11. array奇数偶数: for循环里i+=2改成i++

  12. selection Sort: arr[index_of_min]> arr[x] 改成 > arr[y]

  13. count Digit: while前面加int temp =num, while里面的num改成temp, 最后不能是num%count 在最前面加一个input = num; 最后改成input%count;1111111111111111111111111

  14. remove Duplicates: for循环里k <length改成k < length-1

  15. sum Array: sum =arr改成sum += arr

  16. array Operation: <和>写反了111111111111111111 《=，去=， arr[j] -> 缩进

  17. print1111 : 外层加个括号，外层的for少大括号

    新题目14道：

  18. appear K Times: loop结束后要查一下count和k是否相等，相等的话res = curNum

  19. check Valid Palindrome: return里面num改为temp，num已经被update了 (result == num) → (result == temp)

  20. distinct Element Count: 判断是否重复的flag把0/1写反了if (flag == 1) → if (flag == 0)

  21. count Element: for循环里i < k改成i <size， for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) { if (arr[i] > doubleN) count++; }

  22. sum Distinct: 先sort再初始化sum， 初始化sum数组写在sort之后

  23. remove Vowel: Switch里面default condition移除i++

  24. count Element: 给一个range[low,high]，||改成&&

  25. count Days in leap year: nestedfor loop, ||改成&&

  26. get Digits Sum Parity: num = num/10挪到后面

  27. arm strong: math.pow(result,digitCount)改成pow(remainder,digitCount)

  28. reverse a number: 计算num那里改成reverseNum= reverseNum * 10 + remainder

  29. median Value: arr =arr2 改成arr =arr2[i- size]

  30. count A: &&改成|| if (c == ‘A’ || c == ‘a’)

  31. label Product: str加入的顺序反了 答案：加⼊入字符串串的⽅方向反了了 while 循环中

  32. countDays: (year % 4 == 0) && (year %100 != 0) || (year % 400 == 0)

  33. matrixSum: while(j < n) sum += matrix[i][j++]; put i++ out of the while(j < n) loop

  34. countProduct: for (j = 0; j < size; j++)

oa1练习网站

https://aonecode.com/amazon-online-assessment-debugging-questions#cts

https://aonecode.com/amazon-online-assessment

Debugging
7 questions in 21 mins

2021.1.21号做完，本来以为新年题目会变，不过仍然是广为流传的那7个题目，

Count Rotations: line21 mid - 1 => mid.

Calculate Sum Of Numbers In String : line 13-14 temp = “0” 放进else里面加个大括号.

Check Pair Sum Exists : line19 localSet.add( arr[i] [j]), sum => arr[i] [j]

Remove Consecutive Vowels : line20 && => ||.

Reverse Alphabet Chars Only : line20&21 left++; right–; 放进15-19 的大括号里.

Compare Product : line11&16 digit = num / 10 => digit = num % 10.

Count Triplet Sum Permutations : line10 => for (int j = i + 1….)

Possible bugs:

Count Occurrences ： Missing i++ at the end of while loop
Print Pattern ：Missing { } to wrap up the two lines of code in a for-loop, causing the second line to be excluded from the for-loop.
Insert Sort Descending Order : change ‘>’ (greater than) to ‘<‘ (less than)
Select Sort : change arr[min] > arr[x] to arr[min] > arr[y]
Reverse Array : change arr[len - 1] to arr[len - i - 1] ， remove len += 1 at the end of the loop
Manchester Array : change result=(a[i]==a[i-1]) to result=(a[i]!=a[i-1])，same for ret[0]
Check Grade : change both of || to &&
Replace Even/Odd Values：i <= len and j <= len change into < 6

vowels String: while循环i++放外⾯，最后的返回判断len % 2改成len / 2 ，vcount > (len / 2)

appears K Time: while loop之后return之前加上if (count == k) {res = element;}

  1. add follow code after while loop: if (count == k) res = element;
  2. switch contents in if and else, judge if(element != inputArray[i]) first

check Armstrong: Math.pow()⾥的result改成remainder

count A: c==’A’ && c==’a’中的 && 改成 ||

sum Distinct: 把sort提前

label Product: while循环中加⼊的顺序反了，str = productID.charAt(i) + str 或者 int i = productID.length()-1, while i >=0, i- -

median Value: else后⾯arr[i] = arr2[i-size] else arr[i] = arr2[i] → else arr[i] = arr2[i - size];

count Element Range: || 改成 && (inputArray[i] >= low && inputArray[i] <= high)

get Digit Sum Parity: 1. 返回的判断条件写的都不对 0/1颠倒；2. getSum⾥⾯temp = 的顺序提前

(1)主函数 if (result % 2 ==0) (2)主函数 if (result == 0) return 1 (3)sum digit函数把 int temp = num %10 和 num = num/10 换一下顺序

Tips for Debugging
Sorting functions: most likely give the wrong order.
Fix: Find the key if statement and reverse the condition for comparison.
TLE (Time Limit Exceeded): dead loop WHILE
Fix: check for i++ at the end
FOR loop: missing { }
check whether { } is there for the FOR loops

Design

发表于 2020-12-14 更新于 2021-03-07 分类于 Leetcode

OOD

以亚麻面试官的角度说说如何准备OOD题目

OOD是亚麻SDE1 onsite的必考题目，自己以前准备的时侯网上资料并不多，不像算法可以轻松找到正确答案，OOD基本上只有题目和大家比较简单的讨论，所以自己当时是摸着石头过河，只能反复推敲自己的回答，并没有什么参考标准。好在自己当时onsite的OOD表现还不错。现在开始面试别人的OOD，跟着资深的面试官（当时面我OOD的人😓）学习如何面试OOD。算是有了一些经验，在这分享下自己的心得。

https://www.1point3acres.com/bbs/forum.php?mod=viewthread&tid=717638&extra=page%3D1%26filter%3Dsortid%26sortid%3D311%26sortid%3D311

Design File search with Name and Extension API

Design CD rental system

https://wdxtub.com/interview/14520596997643.html

https://github.com/donnemartin/system-design-primer/blob/master/README-zh-Hans.md

https://www.1point3acres.com/bbs/thread-526497-1-1.html

380. Insert Delete GetRandom O(1)⭐

Solution1:

  1. HashMap + ArrayList Expalanation

  2. implement the structure which provides the following operations in average \mathcal{O}(1)O(1) time:

    • Insert
    • Delete
    • GetRandom

  3. Hashmap provides Insert and Delete in average constant time, although has problems with GetRandom.

  4. Array List has indexes and could provide Insert and GetRandom in average constant time, though has problems with Delete.

  5. To delete a value at arbitrary index takes linear time. The solution here is to always delete the last value:

    • Swap the element to delete with the last one.
    • Pop the last element out.

    For that, one has to compute an index of each element in constant time, and hence needs a hashmap which stores element -> its index dictionary.

    Both ways converge into the same combination of data structures:

    • Hashmap element -> its index.
    • Array List of elements.

Randomlization

Unsolved 519. Random Flip Matrix🎂

Solution1:

382. Linked List Random Node✨

Solution1:

Solution2:

  1. 思路：蓄水池。可以证明，第 i 个数，如果随机数<1/i，则为解。这里我们用<=1/(1+i)。
  2. 详解

353. Design Snake Game✨

Solution1:

  1. 思路：先搞清楚场景：初始状态；死亡状态；移动状态。然后设计主要动作（move）。二维图可以转为一维数组表示，用 Deque 保存蛇体，并用 Set 做索引，因为总是先进后出，且不会有重复数字（注意吃东西时会有 暂时的重复，些时需要先从 Set 中移除尾巴，如果没有问题且吃了东西，再把尾巴加回来。

Unsolved 348. Design Tic-Tac-Toe⭐

Solution0:

  1. brute force

Solution1:

  1. 与 n 后问题思路一致，重点在判断横、竖、斜四个方向上是否已经达到指定数量的相应棋子。

Unsolved LRU Cache(AE)⭐

DoublyLinkedList (track sequence) + Hashtable (access value)

Solution1:

146. LRU Cache✨

Design and implement a data structure for Least Recently Used (LRU) cache. It should support the following operations: get and put

Solution1:

  1. 思路：利用LinkedHashMap的移除最老元素。

  2. 如果不能用该数据结构，可使用双链表+HashMap(key->node)相结 合的方式。

  3. 每次put中get时，同时把相应词移动（或添加）到队尾，并且把原来位置的前后两元素相联。

  4. The problem can be solved with a hashtable that keeps track of the keys and its values in the double linked list. One interesting property about double linked list is that the node can remove itself without other reference. In addition, it takes constant time to add and remove nodes from the head or tail.

  5. One particularity about the double linked list that I implemented is that I create a pseudo head and tail to mark the boundary, so that we don’t need to check the NULL node during the update. This makes the code more concise and clean, and also it is good for the performance.

Solution2:

Unsolved 460. LFU Cache⭐

Unsolved 706. Design HashMap⭐

Solution1:

  1. Some of the questions which can be asked to the interviewer before implementing the solution

    For simplicity, are the keys integers only?
    For collision resolution, can we use chaining?
    Do we have to worry about load factors?
    Can we assume inputs are valid or do we have to validate them?
    Can we assume this fits memory?

  2. Collisions are resolved using linked list

https://leetcode.com/problems/design-hashmap/solution/

Solution1:

362. Design Hit Counter⭐

  1. queue

Solution2:

  1. deque with pair

🌕1429. First Unique Number⭐

Solution1:

OOP : Object-Oriented Programming

什么是对象Object? 万物皆对象

对象的属性和行为

什么是类Class？类是对象的蓝图

什么是OOP?

Class的命名

  1. 首字母大写UpperCamelCase
  2. eg.MyClass

成员变量

  1. 又叫域field
  2. 表示对象的属性
  3. 命名规则和变量名相同

成员函数member function

  1. 又叫方法method
  2. 表示对象的行为
  3. 命名时，第一个但从必须是动词

构造函数Constructor

  1. default constructor
  2. parameterized constructor

OOD

封装：public private

继承：子类父类

抽象：接口interface，类实现接口，重载接口里的method

多态：运算符的重载overload,基于input parameter调整

OOA vs. OOD vs. OOP

基本代表了面试的三个流程步骤：

  1. OOA (Analyze) : 面向对象分析
  2. OOD(Design) : 面向对象设计
  3. OOP(Programming) : 面向对象编程

出题问法

  • Can you design an elevator system? (设计一个完整的系统) • Little amount of coding
  • Can you design scheduler for elevator system? (设计系统中的一个部分) • Need implementation

OOD在面试当中很重要 - 尤其对于Intern和Entry level

题目没有标准答案 - Everything is an object

OOD面试中的陷阱

起手式的陷阱

先下手为强

例子: Okay, for a parking lot, we need multiple levels. Also let’s make it able to park bicycles.

忌：自说自话，侃侃而谈

宜：先通过和面试官的交流获得有效信息，留下一个好的feedback，有一个好的交流

面试官是甲方，不要Assume太多自顾自谈，一万个面试官心中想的是一万个电梯系统，要根据对方的需求确定有效信息进而设计

指鹿为马

例子: Let’s say you need to support 5000 people to park in this parking lot, morning and night will be your peak hour… I can try to use this algorithm/data structure to find the closest spot.

忌：Algorithm, OOD, System design 傻傻分不清楚是哪类题，是算法还是OOD还是System Design

宜：询问清楚题目要求

可以直接问你希望我implement一个算法来支持parking lot里的某一个feature？/设计一个parking lot？/还是一个System可以handle不同时期的traffic？

解题中的陷阱

朝出夕改

例子: Oh, wait a second, I think I can optimize the process by modifying/removing this class

忌：思路混乱，反复修改

宜：先给面试官呈现一个Viable的成果

建议先把解法写好，即便是brute force不是很巧妙也没问题，先完整写出一个解法再去慢慢修改。

收手式的陷阱

虎头蛇尾

忌：虎头蛇尾，功亏一篑

宜：检查你的设计，是否能够支持所需的功能，考虑test case

如何评判一轮OOD面试

S.O.L.I.D原则

S.

Single responsibility principle 单一责任原则

一个类应该有且只有一个去改变他的理由，这意味着一个类应该只有一项工作。

O.

Open close principle 开放封闭原则

对象或实体应该对扩展开放，对修改封闭 (Open to extension, close to modification)。

L.

Liskov substitution principle 里氏替换原则

任何一个子类或派生类应该可以替换它们的基类或父类

I.

Interface segregation principle 接口分离原则

不应该强迫一个类实现它用不上的接口

D

Dependency inversion principle 依赖反转原则

抽象不应该依赖于具体实现，具体实现应该依赖于抽象

Abstract Class-Interface的区别(java的概念)

可以当成一个父类Abstract Class，对以一个子类只能拥有一个父类，extends一个之后不能重复extends

如果是interface可以同时implements很多接口

面试中应该怎么做？

Can you design an elevator system for this building?

奔雷手 - 5C解题法

Clarify

说人话：通过和面试官交流，去除题目中的歧义，确定答题范围

Example: Glass of water ?

清楚歧义，确定对方意图与需求。

  • What
  • How

针对问题主题的规则来提问，帮助自己明确解题方向。

*此类问题没有标准答案，你可以描出一些解决方法，通过面试官的反应， 选择一个你比较有信心（简单）的方案

  • Who

Core objects

说人话：确定题目所涉及的类，以及类之间的映射关系

什么是Core Object 为了完成设计，需要哪些类？

为什么要定义Core Object ?

  • 这是和面试官初步的纸面contract
  • 承上启下，来自于Clarify的结果，成为Use case的依据
  • 为画类图打下基础

如何定义Core Object ?

  • 以一个Object作为基础，线性思考 ,ElevatorSystem
  • 确定Objects之间的映射关系
  • 考虑input，output

Good Practice1 - Access modifier

Access modifier

  • package
  • public
  • private
  • protected

Cases

说人话：确定题目中所需要实现的场景和功能

为什么要写Use cases ?

这是你和面试官白纸黑字达成的第二份共识，把你将要实现的功能列在白板上

帮助你在解题过程中，理清条例，一个一个Case实现

作为检查的标准

怎么写Use cases ?

利用定义的Core Object, 列举出每个Object对应产生的use case.

每个use case只需要先用一句简单的话来描述即可

Classes

说人话：通过类图的方式，具体填充题目中涉及的类

Class diagram (类图)

Class Name
Attributes
Functions

为什么要画类图？

可交付，Minimal Viable Product, 可以上交给別的考官看

节省时间，不容易在Coding上挣扎

建立在Use case上，和之前的步骤层层递进，条例清晰，便于交流和修改

如果时间允许/面试官要求，便于转化成Code

怎么画类图？

遍历你所列出的use cases - 对于每一个use case，更加详细的描述这个use case在做什么事情,填充到Object里 （例如：take external request -> ElevatorSystem takes an external request, and decide to push this request to an appropriate elevator）

针对这个描述，在已有的Core objects里填充进所需要的信息

Use case: Handle request

ElevatorSystem takes an external request, and decide to push this request to an appropriate elevator

Good practice2 - Exception

Use case: Take external request

An elevator takes an external request, inserts in its stop list.

Use case: Open gate

An elevator reaches the destination level, open gate

Use case: Close gate

An elevator checks if overweight; close the door; then check stops corresponds to current status; if no stops left, check the reserve direction stops; change status to reserve direction or idle.

Use case: check weight

An elevator checks its current weight and compare with limit to see if overweight

Use case: press button

A button inside elevator is pressed, will generate an internal request and send to the elevator.

类图，先写出Core Object，列出Use cases

然后按照，Use cases根据自己的节奏完善类图，class 里的各种function

Correctness

说人话：检查自己的设计，是否满足关键点

从以下几方面检查：

  1. Validate use cases (检查是否支持所有的use case)

  2. Follow good practice (面试当中的加分项，展现一个程序员的经验)

  3. S.O.L.I.D

  4. Design pattern

Good Practice - 继承

继承 检查你的设计中，是否有重复的类，可以采用继承的方式来表现

Challenge

AlgoTogether & Interview.io

发表于 2020-11-15 更新于 2021-01-20 分类于 Algorithms

Algotogether

Week 1 Theme: Complex Coding

You should aim for these goals when working through these problems:

  1. Some languages could solve some problems with internal libraries/packages, do NOT use them.
  2. The problems don’t require advance algorithm/data structure, but they either have lots of corner cases or require good coding skills, please try to pass them with 1st attempt.

Technique

Asking clarifying questions

  1. Are they integers?
  2. Is the solution guaranteed?
  3. What if multiple solutions?
  4. Can I assume xxx?

Communication with logical thinking

  1. If it’s okay to return any random solution when there are multiple solutions.
  2. Don’t let your interviewer in the dark.
  3. You can talk a naive solution if you can not come up with advanced approach.

Briefly analyze the time/space complexity

  1. I think time will be O(n) since xxx

Do some error check before code

  1. Empty input, duplicate nums, special cases

Valid palindrome presentation:

  1. Use example, pseudocode to explain you idea.

    Step1, Step2, Step3 make it your language more organized

  2. Initial each variable in a different line;

  3. 使用注释//xx让code更清楚

  4. If else branch, pay attention

  5. Ask interviewer.

    Am I clear, Are you following? Is that make sense to you? Should I make more explanation about it?

Decode String presentation:

  1. Write branch first, then implement
  2. Use demo make your way more Can you teach your grandmother to write this code?
  3. Show the two stack work.
  4. Don’t be nervous.
  5. I know StringBuilder is more efficient. Do you want me to make this improvement?

Rotate Image presentation:

  1. Explain transpose.
  2. Utilize demo.

Tic-Tac-Toe presentation:

  1. Remind X is always first.
  2. Explain in each code block.

Invert Binary Tree Mock Interview

  1. Never say you are not familar with DFS/BFS(or xxx)

Binary Tree Maximum Path Sum Mock Interview

  1. 先沟通思路，Interviewer said direction is right, then start code.
  2. Tell me what is whole path and single path? Don’t have gap in communication.

Week 2 Theme: Binary Search⭐

For most algorithms you have learned from school/programming bootcamp, they probably won’t be used in real-world projects until you touch really low-level infra. Binary Search is considered a basic algorithm that might be required in a real-world project, so it’s frequently asked in interviews.

Some of the problems here can be solved without binary search (explicitly mentioned in the problem statement), but it’s recommended to solve them with binary search which could significantly improve your programming skill.

Technique for interview

Problem solving

  1. Every company have their own scoring system.
  2. Don’t need to get fulll score to apss interview.
  3. Clean non optimal solution > Mess/Half down optimal solution
  4. Coding style is not major factor, but it helps
  5. Go through approach before coding

Communication

  1. English is important, but not critical

  2. Use all tools to help interviewers understand

    • Whiteboard
    • Pseudo Code
  1. Walk Through some examples, test case
  1. When present your solution
    • Talk about high level idea before dive into details implementations
    • Focus on most complicate part
    • For DP, how demo status transition works before into code

Follow up

  1. Fine tuning code (want you thinking corner cases, minor mistakes, typo)
  2. Bonus(if you answer correct, hire -> strong hire)
  3. More challenge
  4. Push for better solution
  5. Redirection the interview to non coding area

Presentation

Search in Rotated Sorted Array

Koko Eating Bananas

Week 3 Theme: BFS & DFS⭐

BFS and DFS are considered fundamental in programming skills. Even they are almost not being used in real-world problems, many companies still using them in most of their interviews.

According to the interview results, when interviewers ask BFS / DFS problems, more than 60% of candidates fail with two main reasons:

  1. Not able to figure out BFS / DFS solution
  2. Not able to code up the solution

Many candidates tend to use DFS over BFS, especially for new grads, but sometimes choosing the correct searching algorithm will significantly improve the performance.

In general, it should be obvious to tell if a particular problem could be solved by BFS or DFS. However, it’s possible that one problem could be solved by both algorithms. In this case, it’s better to evaluate the pros and cons of them first.

Technique

The traverse order matter

  1. A node depends on all shallower nodes:
    • BFS
  2. A node depends on all descendant nodes:
    • DFS
  3. More complex dependency
    • BFS and DFS that dependency tree/graph

Quiz

  1. Shortest path from one leaf to another leaf
    • DFS
    • The shortest path goes up from leaf X through a node Y and then down to leaf Z
    • Path Y to X and path Y to Z must be the two shorest leaf path from Y
    • The shorest leaf path from Y can be calculated fromthe shorest leaf from Y’s child nodes.

DFS

Its recursion form is easy to remember and write. 3 steps in a recursive DFS function:

  1. Take the necessary informations from child nodes.
  2. Compute current node based on current node’s information and those from the child nodes.
  3. Return the computation result in the same data stucture.

Example:

  1. Sum of all node values
  2. Longest path to leaf

DFS Review

  1. Determine how we are going to compute the result for the current node.
  2. Identify what information we ned from child nodes for computation.
  3. Return the similar information after computing the current node.
  4. Chect if leaf node returns the correct information.

BFS

It’s a little bit harder to remoember and write than DFS. However, it only requires 3 steps just like DFS.

  1. Enqueue the root node
  2. Dequeue a node and enqueue all its child nodes.
  3. Repeat indefinitely until the queue is empty.

Example:

  1. Leaf closest to root

    • check it it’s a leaf node
    • stop if it’s a leaf node

  2. Shortest path from point A to point B, can be map in matrix or graph

    • start at point A as step 1, consider it as root
    • identify all adjacent points as step 2 candidates, like child node
    • repeat that for step 3, 4
    • show when point B is identified as candidate of step X

  3. Shortest path from state A to state B

    ​ More variations:

    • A game started with state A. Can it get state B? how to get state B in least amount of steps?
    • A game started with state A. Player X and player Y play against each other. Can it get to state B(eg.X winning or Y winning)?

BFS Review

  1. BFS needs a queue.
  2. The problem might not mention tree or graph.
  3. The problem might involve state transitions.
  4. Memorize visited nodes if it’s a graph.

Sliding Puzzle presentation

  1. Bad : Too many typos. Time complexity, space complexity analyze.
  2. Flow of code is good. Framework first and then implement detail code.
  3. Explain why you choose this data structure, why not other array, etc. Motavitation.
  4. Use examples.
  5. Line 30 : Comment visualize the current data is great //123450 -> x,y
  6. Explain how you achieve BFS’s level search.

Week 4&5 Theme: Data Structure I (Basic) Data Structure II (advanced)

Technique

There are lots of Data Structures we have learned from school. Some of them are considered as basic since

  1. They are easier to understand, and
  2. They are used more often in real-world projects.

For example, Array, Queue, Stack, Heap, Tree, and Hash.

Some others are considered as advance, for example, Interval Tree, Trie, BST, Graph, etc.

For this week, we will focus on the basic data structures, and talk about advanced data structure next week.

For most of the interview questions, they can be solved by basic data structures. However, sometimes we can’t solve the problem by applying a single data structures, optimization is required. For example:

  1. Combine two different data structures together, or
  2. Apply other algorithms on top of it, e.g. Greedy, Sorting, etc.

Advanced Data Structure includes a lot of things, but only a few of them are asked frequently in the interview, they are

  1. Binary Search Tree
  2. Graph (Shortest Path, Minimal Spanning Tree, Topological Sorting)
  3. Trie
  4. Disjoint Set (aka Union Find Set)
  5. Binary Indexed Tree
  6. Interval Tree (aka Segment Tree, together with Line Sweeping)

The above order reflects how often these problems are being asked in the actual interview. Some of these data structures require a template, otherwise, most candidates won’t able to code it up within 45 minutes, which makes it less likely to be asked in interviews.

However, we still have some records that some companies ask candidates these data structures, e.g

  1. Uber, ask Line Sweeping
  2. Google, ask Binary Indexed Tree and Disjoint Set
  3. Facebook and Airbnb, ask Interval Tree

Usually, when the interviewer asks these kinds of problems, the actual data structure might not be the one they are expecting. Try to start with a simple data structure before going into the complicate ones.

For example, Binary Indexed Tree is considered as a simple version of Interval Tree; some features of Trie/Disjoint Set could be achieved by using a regular tree/graph, with higher time complexity.

When the interviewer asks you these questions, I would recommend:

  1. Explicitly ask the interview what are they looking for. You could provide two solutions, a) complicate data structure but lower time/space complexity, and b) simple data structure with better readability but higher time/space complexity. Talk to the interviewer to see what they are looking for.
  2. If you decide to go with the complicate ones, clarify with the interviewer if they want you to implement the actual data structure. Facebook is allowing you to assume the existence of data structure, but Google / Airbnb won’t allow that.
  3. If you have to go with the complicate ones, make sure you think through the problem before start coding. If your original solution doesn’t work, you might not have enough to rewrite your code.

Data structures

  1. Data operations
    • store
    • query
    • update
  2. Core metrics
    • Functionality
    • Time/Space complexity
    • Coding complexity
  3. Basic data structures
    • Array
    • Stack & Queue
      • PriorityQueue(Heap)
    • Hash
  4. Advanced data structures
    • Tree
      • Binary search tree
        • Balance tree
      • Trie
      • Disjoint Set
      • Binary Indexed Tree/Interval Tree
    • Graph
      • Directional Graph
        • Graph DP
        • Topological Sorting
        • Shortest Path
      • Bidirectional Graph
        • Minimal Spanning Tree
  5. Interview
    • Mostly require basic data structures
    • Might require combing data structures/algorithms
      • Stack/Queue
      • Sorting

Basic data structures

Stack and Queue

  • Tracking order
  • Stack, FILO
  • Queue, FIFO
  1. Implement Stack with Queues
  2. Implement Queue with Stacks
  3. Reverse Polish Notation

Priority Queue(Heap)

  • Tree strcture
  • Parent node is minimal(or maximal) of its subtree
  • Tracking running minimal or maximal
  1. Medium in Array
  2. Shorest Path

Hash

  • Converting input objects into keys
  • Tracking info of keys
    • Memorize Recursion(DP)
    • Visited array in BFS
  • HashMap(Java/Cpp) or dict(python)
  1. Implement hash function(start up company)
    • Rabin-Karp Algorithm
  2. Comparing strings

Advanced data structures

  1. Many Advanced data structures
  2. only handfulof them are asked
  3. Choose data structure wisely
    • Clarity requirment(implement? or assume them exist)
    • Explain idea
    • Set exception
  4. Use well-known naming
    • Interval Tree -> Segment Tree
    • Disjoint Set -> Union Find Set

Binary search tree

  1. Preorder/Inorder/Postorder Search
    • Given two of the orders, figure out the rest
  2. Balance Tree
    • Handle BST degeneration
    • More complicated
    • Recommend to use Map/Set/dict

Trie

  1. Prefix tree
  2. Store multiple strings in O(nm) space
    • n is size of alphabet
    • m is lengh of strings
  3. Query string in O(m) sapce

Disjoint Set

  1. Given multiples sets
    • Query ID of set(find)
    • Merge multiple sets(union)
  2. Query Equations

Binary Indexed Tree

  1. Add value into array[index]
  2. Replace array[index] with value
  3. Sum array[index1 : idnex2]

Interval Tree

  1. Replace array[idnex1 : idnex2] with value
  2. Query sum(array[index1 : index2])

Graph

  1. Topological sorting(Run BFS in directional graph)
    • Alien Dictionary
  2. Shorest Path
    • Dijkstra
  3. Minimal Spanning Tree
    • Prim
    • Kruskal

Presentation

Week 6 Theme: Math

Math actually has many different kinds of problems, they are widely used in interviews, especially for startups.

Some typical topics being asked are:

  1. GCD / LCM
  2. Prime numbers
  3. Pigeonhole principle
  4. Geometry
  5. Bit Manipulation
  6. Randomization
  7. Brainteaser

On top of basic mathematical theories, some other algorithms might be required to solve the problems, e.g

  1. Dynamic Programming
  2. DFS / Recursion
  3. Sorting

Technique

  1. Prime
    • Find prime numbers in O(n) space/time
    • Find prime factors in average O(log n) time
  2. GCD/LCM
    • Find GCD /LCM in O(log n) time, O(1) space
  3. Geometry
    • Check if two segments intersect into each other
    • Convex Hull
  4. Bit
    • Calculate +-*/ with bitwise operation
    • Zipping bits into integer
  5. Random
    • Shuffle Array
    • Given a particular randomizer, build a new one on top of
      • Given randomizer from [0, 1], build one from [0, 100]
  6. Brain Teasers
    • Nim
    • Triangle
      • Given a list of integers, find out how many trios could form a triangle

Week 7 Theme: Dynamic Programming⭐

Mock

628. Maximum Product of Three Numbers💜

Solution1:

Follow up

what if input is billion and k is thousand? Can you optimize the complexity to log k?

Use heap.

FeedBack

  1. Advice: never jump to the code before clarify your solution to interview and they said yes.
  2. For any question make sure to ask input type input range, in this case you can ask is stream contain 0, negetive number? And when you deal with lots of number may out of bounds, keep in mind this thing.
  3. Ask clarifying question, ex, in this question, stream is actually a generator, you assuming it’s an array make sure to ask if there are any implicit assumption.
  4. When specifying your approach you can use some pseudo code or English explaition your method. And use some simple examples to walk through.
  5. Edge case. 0 / negetive number. Stream size is less than k, size is larger than bound cause over flow errors when you deal with varaibles. Show you are pay attention to details.
  6. Time Space complexity. Show you are confident with these things.

Binary Tree Anti-clockwise traverse

545. Boundary of Binary Tree

FeedBack

  1. Clarifying question, is binary tree, BST, is there special rules, balanced tree, duplicate value node?
  2. Clarify your approach before coding, talk about time space, think about edge cases.
  3. Eyeball the code. Comment if possible, visilize the data.
  4. If you have multiple approach1,2. You can specify that and make a compare, trade off why you want to do this way.

Cutting a Rod | DP-13

Solution1:

Given a rod of length n inches and an array of prices that contains prices of all pieces of size smaller than n. Determine the maximum value obtainable by cutting up the rod and selling the pieces. For example, if length of the rod is 8 and the values of different pieces are given as following, then the maximum obtainable value is 22 (by cutting in two pieces of lengths 2 and 6)

And if the prices are as following, then the maximum obtainable value is 24 (by cutting in eight pieces of length 1)

Mock1 Top K Frequent Elements⭐

Question(s) asked : Given a non-empty array of integers, return the k most frequent elements

Before coding:

  1. Reading question.
  2. First consider a brute force or a naive way to solve it. And briefly analyze the time/space complexity.
  3. Then talk about the approach. But, choose a data structure and why, make a improvement. Heap. N log k
  4. Ask the feedback, that’s best we can get? I just want to make sure that is the correct direction before start coding.

While coding:

  1. Coding with speaking. And organized.
  2. Write function header, based on input, output
  3. First thing create a dictionary, and then I am gonna look through everything here. Then coding..
  4. And now I need a pq, inside of pq, what do I want? I am gonna need xxx. Then coding..
  5. Next thing I am gonna do is xxx. Then coding..
  6. And I have an array for my result

After Coding:

  1. Analyze : time complexity/ Space complexity.
  2. Each loop part analyze the time complexity, and finally totally overall time complexity will be xx.

Follow up: can we do this O(n) time?

  1. The only thing I can think on top of my head is if input xxx, maybe we can use a bucket sort.
  2. If interviewer saying some hint, thank you for pointing me.
  3. Make a examples, use a bucket to represent the frequency of element
  4. Let use an example in line xx, allocate an array with space of n at most
  5. Shall we try some code?

Mock2 Next largest in BST

Inorder Successor in BST⭐

Before coding:

  1. I am just doing an example make sure I understand the problem.

  2. Assume BST well formed

  3. So if I think any other edge case I will keep track here.

  4. So I think there is couple of cases here.

  5. First a brute force solution: traverse in-order, store each node in output list. Traverse list & return node after given node. Time :O(n) Space: O(n) we need to traverse and also need to store

  6. BCR(best conceivable runtime) for a time perspective is to hit, we should able to do some binary search, we shouldn’t have to traverse every single node. So I think it’s feasible to shoot for somethink like O(log n). Depend on what we implement if recursively space will be O(log n), iterative approach will be O(1) space.

  7. Walking through the example

  8. Cases:

    1. search node has right child -> get smallest element in right subtree
    2. node has no children -> return parent, because it will be next larger element
    3. Search node has no children -> return None
